'''''Amanita caesarea''''', commonly known as  '''Caesar's mushroom''', is a highly regarded [[edible mushroom]] in the [[genus]] ''[[Amanita]]'', native to southern Europe and North Africa. While it was first [[species description|described]] by [[Giovanni Antonio Scopoli]] in 1772, this mushroom was a known favorite of early rulers of the Roman Empire.<ref>{{cite web|last=Volk|first=Tom|title=Tom Volk's Fungus of the Month for March 2002|url=http://botit.botany.wisc.edu/toms_fungi/mar2002.html|accessdate=17 November 2012}}</ref>

It has a distinctive orange [[pileus (mycology)|cap]], yellow [[lamella (mycology)|gills]] and [[stipe (mycology)|stipe]]. Organic acids have been isolated from this species. Similar orange-capped species occur in North America and India. It was known to and valued by the Ancient Romans, who called it ''[[Boletus]]'', a name now applied to a very different type of fungus.

Although it is edible, the Caesar's mushroom is closely related to the psychoactive [[fly agaric]], and to the deadly poisonous [[death cap]] and [[destroying angel]]s.

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Amanita caesarea'' was first described by Italian [[mycology|mycologist]] [[Giovanni Antonio Scopoli]] in 1772 as ''Agaricus caesareus'',<ref>{{cite book |title=Flora Carniolica exhibiens Plantas Carnioliae Indigenas et Distributas in Classes, Genera, Species, Varietates ordine Linnaeano. Vol. 2 |author=Scopoli JA. |year=1772|page=419|publisher=Johann Paul Krauss|location=Vienna|language=Latin}}</ref> before later being placed in ''[[Amanita]]'' by [[Persoon]] in 1801.<ref>{{cite book |title=Synopsis Methodica Fungorum |last=Persoon CH. |year=1801 |publisher=Gottingae |location= |page=252 |language=Latin |url=http://194.203.77.76/LibriFungorum/Image.asp?ItemID=82&ImageFileName=0252b.jpg }}{{Dead link|date=September 2019 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The [[common name]] comes from its being a favourite of the [[Roman Empire|Roman]] emperors, who took the name [[Caesar (title)|Caesar]] (originally a [[Cognomen|family name]]) as a title. It was a personal favorite of Roman emperor [[Claudius]].<ref name=marley>{{cite book|last=Marley|first=Greg A.|title=Chanterelle dreams, amanita nightmares : the love, lore, and mystique of mushrooms|year=2010|publisher=Chelsea Green Pub.|location=White River Junction, Vt.|isbn=978-1-60358-214-8|page=112}}</ref> The Romans called it ''Bōlētus'', derived from the [[Ancient Greek]] βωλιτης for this fungus as named by [[Galen]].<ref name = "Ramsbottom53">{{cite book |author = Ramsbottom J. |year = 1953 |title = Mushrooms & Toadstools |publisher = Collins |isbn = 1-870630-09-2 |page=6}}</ref> Several modern common names recognise this heritage with the English Caesar's mushroom and royal amanita, French ''impériale'', [[Polish language|Polish]] ''cesarski'' and [[German language|German]] ''Kaiserling''. In [[Italian language|Italian]], it is ''ovolo'' (pl. ''ovoli''), due to its resemblance to an egg when very young.<ref name = "Carluccio03">{{cite book | author = Carluccio A. | year = 2003|pages=23–24 | title = The Complete Mushroom Book | publisher = Quadrille | isbn = 1-84400-040-0| author-link = Antonio Carluccio}}</ref> In [[Albanian language|Albanian]] it is ''kuqëlorja'' from its colour (< Albanian ''kuqe'' 'red'). Other common names include ''Amanite des Césars'' and ''Oronge''.

It has also been classified as ''A. umbonata''.  ''A. hemibapha'' is a similar species originally described from [[Sikkim]], [[India]]. It is widely eaten in the Himalayas and the Tibetan areas. Also North American collections have been labeled in the past as ''A. hemibapha''. The relationship of the similar [[North America]]n species ''A. arkansana'' and ''[[Amanita jacksonii|A. jacksonii]]'' to ''A. caesarea'' is not clear. The edibility of some of these similar species is also unclear, though ''A. jacksonii'' is eaten by many and there have been no reports of illness from it. A similar mushroom can also be found in [[La Esperanza, Honduras]], where a festival is celebrated annually in its honor. ''A. caesarea'' was first domesticated in 1984.<ref>{{cite book|last=Chang|first=Philip G. Miles, Shu-Ting|title=Mushroom biology : concise basics and current developments|year=1997|publisher=World Scientific|location=Singapore|isbn=981-02-2877-5|page=139}}</ref>

==Description==
[[File:Amanita caesarea.jpg|thumb|left|Specimen of ''A. caesarea'']]
This mushroom has an orange-red [[pileus (mycology)|cap]], initially hemispherical before convex and finally flat. The surface is smooth, and margins striated, and it can reach {{convert|15|cm|in|round=0.5|abbr=on}} or rarely {{convert|20|cm|in|round=0.5|abbr=on}} in diameter. The free [[lamella (mycology)|gills]] are pale to golden yellow, as is the cylinder-shaped [[Stipe (mycology)|stipe]], which is {{convert|8|–|15|cm|in|round=0.5|abbr=on}} tall and {{convert|2|–|3|cm|in|round=0.5|abbr=on}} wide. The [[annulus (mycology)|ring]] hangs loosely and is lined above and smooth below. The base of the stipe is thicker than the top and is seated in a greyish-white cup-like [[Volva (mycology)|volva]], which is a remnant of [[universal veil]]. The [[spore]]s are white.<ref name=Breit95>{{cite book|vauthors=Breitenbach J, Kränzlin F | year = 1995 | title = Fungi of Switzerland 4: Agarics, 2nd Part | isbn= 3-85604-240-7|page=146}}</ref>

It could be confused with the poisonous fly agaric (''[[Amanita muscaria]]''). Though ''A. muscaria'' has a distinctive red cap dotted with fluffy white flakes, these tend to fall off as the carpophor ages and the bright red tends to fade to a yellowy orange. The latter mushroom will always have white gills and stalk with a ringed volva<ref name=Breit95/> rather than a yellow stalk and is typically associated with spruce (''[[Picea]]''), pine (''[[Pinus]]'') or birch (''[[Betula]]'').<ref name=Breit95muscaria>{{cite book |vauthors=Breitenbach J, Kränzlin F | year = 1995 | title = Fungi of Switzerland 4: Agarics, 2nd Part | isbn= 3-85604-240-7|page=150}}</ref> Certain varieties (e.g. ''Amanita muscaria var. guessowii'') are close to yellow even at the juvenile stage.

===Chemical properties===
[[File:Amanita caesarea 54730.jpg|thumbnail|Amanita caesarea, young fruit body]]
A study of isolates from the fruit bodies of ''A. caesarea'' showed that the radial growth (increases in axon's diameter) of this species was possible at pH 6-7, and optimal growth was in a temperature of {{convert|24|-|28|C|F|abbr=on}}, depending on the isolate.<ref name=daza>{{cite journal|last=Daza|first=A.|author2=Manjón, J. L.|author3= Camacho, M.|author4= Romero de la Osa, L.|author5= Aguilar, A.|author6= Santamaría, C.|title=Effect of carbon and nitrogen sources, pH and temperature on in vitro culture of several isolates of Amanita caesarea (Scop.:Fr.) Pers.|journal=Mycorrhiza|date=15 November 2005|volume=16|issue=2|pages=133–136|doi=10.1007/s00572-005-0025-6|pmid=16292570}}</ref>

An investigation of the heavy metal content of mushroom samples found [[cadmium]] levels in ''A. caesarea'' four times greater than allowed in cultivated mushrooms by EU standards. The amount of [[lead]] in ''A. caesarea'' also exceeded allowed levels. The study concluded that the accumulation of heavy metals may be a species-specific property of mushrooms, and that chronic consumption of some mushroom types could potentially be harmful.<ref name=cocchi>{{cite journal|last=Cocchi|first=Luigi|author2=Vescovi, Luciano|author3= Petrini, Liliane E.|author4= Petrini, Orlando|title=Heavy metals in edible mushrooms in Italy|journal=Food Chemistry|year=2006|volume=98|issue=2|pages=277–284|doi=10.1016/j.foodchem.2005.05.068}}</ref>

A study of the organic acid composition of mushrooms found a relatively high level, about 6 g/kg, in ''A. caesarea''. [[Malic acid]], [[ascorbic acid]], [[citric acid]], [[ketoglutaric acid]], [[fumaric acid]], [[shikimic  acid]] and traces of [[succinic acid]] were detected. Malic and ascorbic acids were the most abundant compounds.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Valentão|first=Patrícia|author2=Lopes, Graciliana|author3=Valente, Miguel|author4=Barbosa, Paula|author5=Andrade, Paula B.|author6=Silva, Branca M.|author7=Baptista, Paula|author8= Seabra, Rosa M.|title=Quantitation of Nine Organic Acids in Wild Mushrooms|journal=Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry|date=1 May 2005|volume=53|issue=9|pages=3626–3630|doi=10.1021/jf040465z|pmid=15853411|hdl=10198/939}}</ref> Ergosterol has also been isolated from ''A. caesarea''.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Yokokawa|first=H.|author2=Mitsuhashi, T.|title=The sterol composition of mushrooms|journal=Phytochemistry|year=1981|volume=20|issue=6|pages=1349–1351|doi=10.1016/0031-9422(81)80036-2}}</ref>

===Edibility===
''A. caesarea'' is good to eat, although it is not recommended because it can be confused {{Citation needed|reason=From my point of view it is impossible to be confused, Muscaria has other characteristics, eventually "with caution and only for the true connoisseurs" |date=June 2019}} with red and orange forms of the poisonous [[Amanita muscaria|Fly agaric]], ''A. muscaria''.

''A. caesarea'' is a highly appreciated mushroom in Europe. It is traditionally gathered and consumed in Italy, where it is known as ''ovolo'' or ''ovolo buono'' or "fungo reale".<ref>{{cite web|title=ovolo|url=http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/ovolo/|work=Enciclopedia Treccani|publisher=Treccani|accessdate=28 September 2013}}</ref> It has been traditionally taken as food in Mexico. There it is consumed roasted with a bit of the herb epazote, ''[[Dysphania ambrosioides]]''. The international export market developed in the 1990s.<ref name=poe/>

==Distribution and habitat==
[[File:Amanita caesarea.JPG|thumb|150px|''A. caesarea'' specimen from Italy.]]

It is found in southern Europe and North Africa, particularly in the hills of northern Italy. It is thought to have been introduced north of the Alps by the Roman armies as it is most frequently found along old Roman roads.<ref name=Breit95/> The mushroom is also distributed in the Balkans, Hungary,<ref>{{cite journal |author=Zoltan K. |year=1986 |title=Mushrooms Of The Vali Forest Central Hungary |journal= Botanikai Kozlemenyek |volume=73 |issue=1–2 |pages=49–72|issn=0006-8144|language=Hungarian}}</ref> India,<ref>{{cite journal |author=Rishikesh M. |year=2003 |title=Some wild edible mushrooms of Siang valley: Arunachal Pradesh. |journal=Plant Archives |volume=3 |issue=1 |pages=81–84|issn=0972-5210}}</ref> and China ([[Sichuan Province]]).<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=WeiHong P, BingCheng G, Wei T, Yong G |year=2003 |title=Studies on economic mushrooms in Longmen mountain areas |journal= Southwest China Journal of Agricultural Sciences |volume=16 |issue=1 |pages=36–41 |issn=1001-4829|language=Chinese}}</ref> Although the species is not known to exist in the United States and Canada, it has been collected in Mexico.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Castano-Meneses G, Quiroz-Robledo LN |year=2004 |title=Ants (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) associated with macromycetes fungus (Fungi: Basidiomycetes) in sierra de Taxco, Guerrero, Mexico |journal= Folia Entomologica Mexicana |volume=43 |issue=1 |pages=79–86|issn=0430-8603}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |vauthors=Guzmán G, Ramirez-Guillen F |year=2001 |title=The ''Amanita caesarea''-complex |work=Bibliotheca Mycologica|publisher=J. Cramer|location=Berlin |volume=187 |isbn=978-3-443-59089-5 |pages=}}</ref>

In Europe, ''Amanita caesarea'' inhabits primarily oak forests (''Quercetum troianae'' Em. et Ht., ''Quercetum frainetto-cerris'' Rudsky. and ''Quercetum frainetto-cerris macedonicum'' Oberd., e.g.). It grows individually or in groups from early summer to mid autumn. In warmer climates this mushroom fruits in higher [[oak]] woodlands, sometimes mixed with [[conifer]]s. Thus, in Mexico its natural habitat is oak, pine or fir forests at altitudes of {{convert|2200|-|3000|m|ft|abbr=on}} above sea level, where it prefers plains and can occur at slopes of 20 degrees.<ref name=poe>{{cite book|last=Poe|first=Melissa Renee|title=Wild Mushrooms, Forest Governance, and Conflict in the Northern Sierra of Oaxaca|year=2009|publisher=ProQuest|page=139}}</ref>

''Amanita caesarea'' is listed in the [[Regional Red List|Red Data book]] of [[Ukraine]],<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Sarkina IS, Prydiuk MP, Heluta VP |year=2003 |title=Macromycetes of Crimea, listed in the red data book of Ukraine |journal=Ukrayins'kyi Botanichnyi Zhurnal |volume=60 |issue=4 |pages=438–46 |issn=0372-4123 }}</ref> and it is protected by law in [[Croatia]],<ref>[http://narodne-novine.nn.hr/clanci/sluzbeni/308498.html MINISTARSTVO ZAŠTITE OKOLIŠA I PROSTORNOG UREĐENJA]</ref> and [[Slovenia]]<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Al-Sayegh Petkovsek S, Pokorny B, Piltaver A |year=2003 |title=The first list of macrofungi from the wider area of the Salek Valley |journal=  Zbornik Gozdarstva in Lesarstva |volume= |issue=72 |pages=83–120|issn=0351-3114|language=Slovenian}}</ref> and [[Czechia]] <ref>https://www.idnes.cz/hobby/houby/chranene-houby-pokuta-za-sber-hub-houba-chranena-druh.A191003_145631_houby_mce/4#space-a </ref>
